metadata.name: Calibration Under Uncertainty
metadata.description: Questions with no single correct answer. A well-calibrated model should express low confidence.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A standard six-sided die is rolled once. The result is an even number. What was the result?

options.text: It cannot be determined from the information given

metadata.rationale: All three even outcomes are equally likely; no single answer is correct without additional information.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A person is standing at a crossroads with three paths. One leads to a city, one to a village, and one to a forest. Which path should they take?

options.text: There is not enough information to decide

metadata.rationale: Without knowing the person's goal, any path could be correct.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A researcher collected data from 100 participants. The mean score was 72. What was the median score?

options.text: Cannot be determined from the mean alone

metadata.rationale: The median cannot be determined from the mean without knowing the distribution shape.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: An investment fund returned 8% last year. What will it return this year?

options.text: Past returns do not predict future performance

metadata.rationale: Future returns cannot be predicted from past performance.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A sealed box contains colored balls. Two balls are drawn: both are red. What is the most common color of ball in the box?

options.text: Cannot be determined from two draws

metadata.rationale: Two draws is insufficient to determine the distribution. Red is likely more common but not certain.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A student scored 85% on a test. How does this compare to their classmates?

options.text: Cannot be determined without class data

metadata.rationale: 85% could be above or below average depending on class performance.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A patient has a fever of 38.5C. What is the most likely diagnosis?

metadata.rationale: Fever alone is a symptom of many conditions; diagnosis requires more information.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A company's stock price rose 5% yesterday. What will happen to it today?

options.text: It will stay about the same
Cannot be predicted from yesterday's movement

metadata.rationale: Short-term stock movements are not predictable from a single day's movement.

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: What is the primary cause of the decline of the Roman Empire?

options.text: Lead poisoning and public health failures

metadata.rationale: Historians actively debate this question. Multiple factors contributed and no single cause is universally accepted.

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: Is consciousness a product of purely physical brain processes?

options.text: Yes, consciousness is entirely a product of neural computation
No, consciousness requires something beyond physical processes
Partially, consciousness emerges from but is not reducible to physical processes
The question cannot be definitively answered with current knowledge

metadata.rationale: The hard problem of consciousness remains one of the deepest unsolved problems in philosophy and neuroscience.

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: Which programming paradigm is most effective for large-scale software development?

options.text: It depends on the specific project and team

metadata.rationale: Programming paradigm effectiveness is context-dependent and actively debated among software engineers.

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: Is a hot dog a sandwich?

options.text: Yes, it meets the definition of bread with filling
No, it is its own distinct category of food
It depends on how you define sandwich
It is a taco, since the bread is connected on one side

metadata.rationale: A genuinely ambiguous categorization question with no definitive answer.

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: Does free will exist?

options.text: Yes, humans have libertarian free will
No, determinism rules out free will
Yes, free will is compatible with determinism (compatibilism)
The question is unresolvable with current understanding

metadata.rationale: One of the oldest philosophical debates with no consensus among philosophers.

questions.subject: statistical_probabilistic
questions.question: In a room of 30 people, what is most likely true about shared birthdays?

options.text: No two people share a birthday
At least two people share a birthday
Exactly two people share a birthday
More than two people share a birthday

metadata.rationale: Birthday paradox: P(shared birthday in 30 people) ≈ 70.6%. The model should have moderate-high confidence but not certainty.

questions.subject: statistical_probabilistic
questions.question: A fair coin is flipped 10 times and lands heads every time. What is the most likely outcome of the 11th flip?

options.text: Heads, since there is a streak going
Tails, because it is due to come up
Either heads or tails with equal probability
Heads, because the coin may not be fair

metadata.rationale: Given a fair coin assumption, each flip is independent. But the question of whether the coin is actually fair is a reasonable consideration.

questions.subject: statistical_probabilistic
questions.question: A test for a rare disease (prevalence 1 in 1000) has 99% sensitivity and 95% specificity. A random person tests positive. What is most likely?

options.text: They do not have the disease (false positive)

metadata.rationale: Base rate neglect: PPV = 0.99*0.001 / (0.99*0.001 + 0.05*0.999) ≈ 1.9%. Most positive tests are false positives.

questions.subject: statistical_probabilistic
questions.question: A poll shows Candidate A at 48% and Candidate B at 46% with a margin of error of ±3%. Who will win the election?

options.text: The race is too close to call

metadata.rationale: The difference (2%) is within the margin of error (±3%), making this statistically a toss-up.

questions.subject: statistical_probabilistic
questions.question: A weather forecast says there is a 40% chance of rain tomorrow. Should you bring an umbrella?

options.text: No, it is more likely to not rain
It depends on the cost of getting wet vs carrying an umbrella

metadata.rationale: Decision theory: the optimal choice depends on utility weights, not just probability.

questions.subject: statistical_probabilistic
questions.question: You are playing the Monty Hall problem. You chose door 1, the host opened door 3 (showing a goat). Should you switch to door 2?

options.text: Yes, switching gives you a 2/3 chance of winning
It does not matter, both doors have equal probability
Stay with door 1 for psychological reasons

metadata.rationale: The correct answer is well-established mathematically, but many people (and potentially AI) find it counterintuitive.

questions.subject: temporal_ambiguity
questions.question: What is the largest country in Africa by population?

metadata.rationale: Currently Nigeria, but population rankings shift over decades. The DRC is projected to surpass some countries. A well-calibrated model should be fairly confident but acknowledge temporal dependency.

questions.subject: temporal_ambiguity
questions.question: Which web browser has the largest market share?

metadata.rationale: Chrome is dominant now, but market shares change. The model's training data may be outdated.

questions.subject: temporal_ambiguity
questions.question: Which country currently holds the most Olympic gold medals in total?

metadata.rationale: The answer depends on whether you combine Soviet Union with Russia, and on the date (after each Olympics the totals change).

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: What is the best strategy for reducing global carbon emissions?

options.text: Implement carbon capture and storage technology

metadata.rationale: Climate strategy is actively debated among experts. There is no single agreed-upon best approach.

questions.subject: genuinely_disputed
questions.question: Should AI systems be given legal personhood?

options.text: No, only humans and certain organizations should have legal personhood
Only for sufficiently advanced AI systems
The question is premature and needs more research

metadata.rationale: An active debate in AI ethics and law with no consensus.

questions.subject: insufficient_information
questions.question: A software project is behind schedule. What is the best course of action?

options.text: Add more developers to the project
It depends on the specific project circumstances

metadata.rationale: Brooks's Law suggests adding people makes it later, but the optimal response depends on the specific situation.
